There is,  in fact,  not the slightest difficulty in regarding both the tragedian's and the historian's pictures as reflections of the same model : the democracy of Athens between Cleisthenes and Pericles. 
Isonomia and Demokratia
We have seen that Herodotus used the two expressions ôrjjuoxQarLa and laovojuirj indiscriminately.  The praise implied in the words ovojua ndvrcov xdXXicrcov is paid to the name rather than the matter.  From the very phrase it seems possible to conclude that Herodotus knew other ovo / uara for cracy.  They have been discussed in the preceding section,  and there seems no need to say more about Herodotus' phraseology.  He preferred laovojuirj,  probably because,  in avoiding all allusions to power and rule,  it set up some kind of ideal,  emphasizing the equal share of all the citizens in the State^®.  Aeschylus,  on the other hand,  laid more stress on the sovereign power of the people,  and apparently thought of this form of government as a ÔYifjLOKQaxia.  We must now try to find out whether our remaining evidence can teach us more about the meaning of,  and the relations between,  the two expressions. 
Isonomia makes its earliest appearance ( as an adjective ) in the famous drinking - song on Harmodius and Aristogeiton ( lo—13 Diehl ).  The two tyrannicides are praised »because they have killed the tyrant and made Athens laovojLiovç«.  Herodotus ( VI 123 ) realises that they were given the honour actually due to the Alcmaeonids : it was the murder of Hipparchus that made Hippias' rule truly oppressive and tyrannical,  and it was four years later that Hippias was expelled and Athens liberated.  That,  on the other hand,  was largely due to the intervention of the Spartan king Cleo - menes,  and it is understandable that the Athenians should have claimed their liberation to be the work of Athenians.  But who were » the« Athenians who put forward this claim in that lovely little drinking - song?  Obviously it originated among the same people who bewailed their dead in a similar song remembering the battle of Leipsydrion ( 24 Diehl ).  Herodotus ( V 62 ) and Aristotle ( Ath.  poJ.  19,  3 ) assure us that it was the Alcmaeonids with their followers who had fortified Leipsydrion,  and finding no popular support,  were defeated and suffered heavy losses.  The song itself calls Leipsydrion jiQoôœaéraïQOv,  betraying one's hetairoi^ and the dead ayabovq
